) The purpose of this section is to provide International Individual Compliance (IIC) examiners and managers procedural guidance for examining tax returns Scope and for the IIC taxpayer population. (
) Audience: This IRM applies primarily to IIC examiners, which includes revenue agents, tax compliance officers and tax examiners. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Withholding and International Individual Compliance (WIIC) (
) Program Owner: The Director, WIIC manages and administers the WIIC Practice Area. (

) Program Goals: The goals of the WIIC Practice Area align with the LB&I Strategic Goal to apply the tax laws with integrity and fairness through a skilled and satisﬁed workforce, in an environment of inclusion where each employee can make a maximum contribution to the mission of the team. (
) WIIC was established as one of nine practice areas within the LB&I in February

) This section provides an explanation of the basic standards and responsibilities that all IIC examiners must understand and apply in the performance of their duties. (

) IIC examiners and managers should be familiar with and use the examination procedures and information contained in this IRM and also be aware of the applicable procedures in other examination IRM chapters, as cited or linked. (

) All IIC examiners will use the latest version of forms and letters available in electronic format on the Forms/Pubs/Products Repository, http://publish.no.irs. gov/catlg.html. It is acceptable to use the version of forms and letters in RGS until next RGS update unless IIC examiners are informed otherwise. (

) Providing all taxpayers with high quality service in all contacts is a primary area of emphasis for all IIC examination employees. All IIC examiners must perform their professional responsibilities in a way that supports the IRS Mission. IIC examiners are to provide top quality service and administer tax laws fairly and equitably, protect taxpayer rights and treat each taxpayer ethically, with honesty, integrity and respect. (

) Taxpayers have the right to receive assistance from the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) if the IRS has not resolved their tax issues properly and through normal channels. Refer taxpayers to TAS when the contact meets criteria (see IRM
, Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria). (
) IIC examiners should assist taxpayers in resolving any tax problems during an examination, even if the problems are not directly related to the amination. (
) IIC examiners should request assistance from customer service personnel, needed to expedite resolution of taxpayer problems. (
) IIC examiners contact the Taxpayer Advocate when appropriate. (

) IIC examiners should make referrals to appropriate SB/SE ATAT Collection personnel if taxpayers have questions about current or past collection If a taxpayer requests information about collection actions taken against a former or separated spouse, this request should also be referred to personnel. (
) IIC examiners should refer to IRM
, Examination Technical Time System, to determine the appropriate time reporting codes to use when assisting taxpayers in solving problems that are unrelated to an ongoing amination. (

) The effective use of time is an essential element of a quality examination. WIIC examiners are responsible for the day-to-day management of their and are accountable for completing their work in the least amount of time necessary to perform a quality audit. Both the number of hours charged to case and the span of time the case is open must be reasonable.

Taxpayers have the right to receive assistance from the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) if the IRS has not resolved their tax issues properly and timely through normal channels. Refer taxpayers to TAS when the contact meets TAS criteria (see IRM 13.1.7, Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria).

language. This interaction must not only be clear and professional, but also productive as to establish a positive rapport with the taxpayer throughout the examination. These skills are particularly important for tax examiners whose case work is generally completed entirely via phone and/or correspondence. (

) The following are important tips applicable to all IIC examiners but speciﬁc to phone and/or correspondence examinations: a. Identify the taxpayer’s issue during the phone call to determine resolution. b. Provide accurate and complete information. c. Be courteous and professional, regardless of the opposing party’s behavior. d. Steer the direction of the conversation, remaining focused on the of the call. e. Take ownership of the call and address issues raised. f. Make helpful and productive referrals, as applicable. g. Ensure that the taxpayer clearly understands the next case actions to taken. h. Review IDRs and get commitment to the response due dates. (
) All taxpayer correspondence must be clear, concise, and professional, as as adhering to legal requirements. (

) Write in plain language. A document is written in plain language if readers read it once and ﬁnd what they need, understand what they ﬁnd, and use they ﬁnd to meet their needs. Examiners may refer to the Plain Language website for additional guidance, www.plainlanguage.gov. (
) All correspondence should strive to meet the needs of the taxpayer. (
) Where possible, all correspondence with taxpayers should be prepared using the applicable standard forms and letters. (

) All correspondence must contain an employee name, contact telephone number, employee identiﬁcation number, and signature. See IRM Initial Contact for IIC Revenue Agent (RA) Examination Cases and Tax ance Officer (TCO) Cases, and IRM
, Initial Contact for IIC Tax Examiner (TE) Cases, for information on the appropriate letters to use. (

) Any original correspondence prepared by examiners will be approved by the team manager and such approval will be documented in the case ﬁle. If spondence is not individually approved due to an exception, managers must develop an ongoing review process to ensure the quality of correspondence. (
) IIC teams that do not use form letters should maintain read ﬁles of all correspondence. (

, Your Rights as a Taxpayer, and must be shared with the taxpayer along with Notice
, Privacy Act Notice, at the initial contact in person or by mail.

) Auditing includes the accumulation of evidence for evaluating the accuracy the taxpayer’s tax return(s). Evidence takes many forms, including (but not exclusive to) the taxpayer’s testimony, the taxpayer’s books and records, examiner’s own observations and third-party documentation. (

) It is important to obtain sufficient evidence to determine the accuracy of taxpayer’s return. ) Factors to consider when establishing the depth of the examination a. The risk that the taxpayer has made errors that are individually or tively material. The factors involved are addressed during the evaluation of the knowledge of the tax law and/or use of a tax preparer. (

) If a taxpayer is contacted about an Information Return Processing (IRP) the scope of the examination is generally limited to resolving differences between items reported by the taxpayer and items reported on the returns. , Partner’s/Shareholder’s Share of Income, Credits, etc., is inspected to determine that the ﬂow through items have reported correctly, the taxpayer and/or representative should be advised the inspection does not constitute an examination of the ﬂow-through entity and the taxpayer’s distributions from the related entity may be adjusted the related entity is examined. ) Generally, short-term timing issues should not be examined. Timing issues long-term, indeﬁnite or permanent deferral features should be examined. Unplanned timing issues which arise as correlative adjustments during an amination of non-timing issues should be made if it is cost effective. (

) Treasury Enforcement and Communication System (TECS) is a information system designed to identify individuals and businesses of or involved in violations of Federal law. TECS provides access to the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), National Crime Information Center (NCIC), and the National Law Enforcement Telecommunication Systems (NLETS) with the capability of communicating directly with state and local forcement agencies. NLETS provides direct access to state motor vehicle departments. TECS provides information to us that may not otherwise be available to the Service, such as where a taxpayer has traveled. (

) To access TECS, the user must request access through his/her system istrator. The System Control Officer (SCO) in their ﬁeld office will then a User Proﬁle Record on TECS. The user will be required to take an Security/Privacy Awareness Course and a National Crimes Information (NCIC) test. Instructions will be provided by the user’s SCO. The user retake these tests every two years for recertiﬁcation. (

) TECS also contains historical travel information of taxpayers. TECS extensive records of commercial airline ﬂight arrivals and departures. also contains other records of air and sea travel, records of border and the speciﬁc dates that individuals have traveled to and from the United States. (

) The travel information in TECS can facilitate collection of delinquent from taxpayers who are not subject to ordinary administrative and judicial lection procedures because they often reside outside the jurisdiction of the Courts. This travel information may lead to the discovery of where the has assets or conducts business activity. Additionally, TECS travel can help determine the taxpayer’s correct country of current residency. (

Conclusion – Document a conclusion summarizing the disposition of each issue. c. Audit Steps – Document references to the supporting workpapers that contain the procedures and the audit techniques performed during the audit. Steps that are not should be deleted and additional steps could be added when warranted. d. Facts – Document the facts upon which the adjustment is based. give the Commissioner speciﬁc authority to take immediate assessment and collection action in situations where it is deter- mined that collection of tax will be endangered if regular assessment and collection procedures are followed. A jeopardy assessment is used only IRS makes its determination after the end of the tax year to which it relates. a termination assessment, the determination is made before the related tax year ends or before the date to ﬁle a return and pay the tax. See IRM
, Jeopardy/Termination Assessments. (
) Jeopardy/termination assessments of tax are to be used sparingly. They are be reasonable, appropriate, and limited to amounts which can be expected protect the government. (

) The mere fact that a taxpayer is the subject of a special fraud investigation is not sufficient grounds for a jeopardy/termination assessment. When it is mined that a taxpayer has few collectable assets to offset the assessment, jeopardy/termination assessments should, generally, not be pursued. (

) Examination is responsible for recommending jeopardy/termination assess- ments in cases under active consideration by Examination. (

) Appeals may forward a report to Examination, on a case pending before Appeals, for Examination to determine if a jeopardy/termination situation Examination must limit its investigation to a determination of whether the col- lection of the currently proposed deﬁciency will be endangered if regular assessment and collection procedures are followed. ) The term “manual assessment” (also referred to as “prompt” or “quick” ments) refers to the method used to make an assessment of tax, whether and or all of the tax is assessed. Most tax assessments made for examination cases are done via an AIMS command code. AIMS then sends the assess- ment information to master ﬁle. AIMS will accumulate all assessment done this way and reﬂects the total on accomplishment reports when the is closed. (

) There are instances when an assessment must be made expeditiously in to protect the government’s interest. In these instances, the assessment is made manually (entered directly into Master File). When assessments are done manually, AIMS is by-passed so the amount is not reﬂected in the lative total in AIMS. (

) The term “partial assessment” means that only part of the total potential tax agreed to and is being assessed. The most common example of a situation that would generate the required procedures for a Partial Assessment is the taxpayer agrees to some adjustments and appeals other adjustments. In this situation, a partial assessment should be formalized for the agreed of the tax prior to forwarding the case to Appeals for the unagreed portion. (

) Other situations where partial assessments are used include: a. When adjustments to a TEFRA partnership are agreed and ﬂow to one the partners whose return includes the potential for additional adjust- ments. Upon receiving the RAR for the partnership case, a partial assessment should be made for the ﬂow-through issues while to work the individual’s return. b. When a secured delinquent return has issues that warrant further nation (or has a math error). The delinquent return must ﬁrst be processed so that an assessment for the amounts shown on the return can be made. (

-B, Identity Theft Case Referral, send it to the respective Identity Theft Coordinator in PSP. If an examiner receives a Form
